economic_context.details: Barbe claimed she left Ville-sur-Illon because of poverty. She worked as an itinerant healer, charging for her services. Multiple witnesses accused her of fraud - extracting money, food, clothing, and other goods (scarves, sheets, napkins, hair locks) for pilgrimages and cures that didn't work. Barbe confessed under torture to killing her nephew Demenge Voyant of le Grand Frizon 'because he took her property and did her wrong.'

extraction_metadata.notes: Very detailed trial record with extensive witness testimony. 20 witnesses provided testimony over multiple sessions. Barbe was an itinerant healer who practiced folk medicine, collecting herbs with elaborate rituals. She was accused of fraud and witchcraft after many patients died or were not cured. Under torture she confessed to being seduced by 'Mre Augustin' who taught her about harmful herbs. She confessed to killing several people including her nephew, and accused another woman (Poinsotte) of witchcraft. Trial shows complex social dynamics around healing, reputation, economic transactions, and community suspicion. Notable that 2 pages of confrontations are missing from the document. Barbe was executed by burning on August 5, 1591.
